According to Rule 69(1) of the Rules of Procedure of the Boards of Appeal (RAPP), 'the unitary effect of a European patent comes into existence at the date of the grant of that patent.' In this case, the mention of the grant of EP-X was published on 2 October 2024. Since unitary effect had been registered for EP-X-C0 on the same day (10 October 2024), the unitary effect came into existence with respect to the entire European patent application EP-X.\n\nAs a result, when unitary effect is granted, all national units are treated as if they were one. Therefore, only one renewal fee needs to be paid for the European patent as a whole. According to Rule 106(2) of the Rules for the Examination of Patents (REFP), 'the 5th year runs from the date on which the European patent was granted.' Thus, the first renewal fee is due in October 2025 for EP-X-C0.\n\n- **Option A** is incorrect because it states that a renewal fee still has to be paid by 31 October 2024 for the 5th year. However, according to Rule 106(2), the first renewal fee period starts from the grant date.\n\n- **Option C** is also incorrect as it suggests paying a renewal fee on 31 October 2024 for the 6th year, which is not applicable until October 2025.\n\n- **Option D** states that no renewal fee has to be paid by 31 October 2024. This would be incorrect because, as per Rule 106(2), a renewal fee is due in the month following the grant date for the first year of protection, which is October 2025.\n\nTherefore, since unitary effect has been registered on 10 October 2024 and comes into existence from that day, the correct statement is B: A renewal fee is due on 31 October 2024 in respect of the 5th year for EP-X-C0.

According to Article 94(3) of the European Patent Convention (EPC), where a period is set for four months, it means that time starts from the date when the letter or communication was posted, not necessarily the day it was received by the recipient. In this case, the communication setting the four-month time limit for reply was dated 12 September 2024 and was received on 21 September 2024.

To calculate the last day of the period:
- The first day is 21 September 2024 (the day after posting, as the letter was signed by the recipient).
- Counting four months from that date brings us to 21 January 2025.
- Since we need the last full calendar day within this four-month period, the reply should be received on or before 12 January 2025.

Option B is correct because:
- The time limit starts from 21 September 2024 (the day after posting).
- Adding four months lands us on 12 January 2025.

Why other options are incorrect:

A. 13 January 2025 - This date would be one day too late, as the correct deadline is before this date.
C. 22 January 2025 - This date is more than a month after the last day of the four-month period and therefore incorrect.
D. 14 January 2025 - This date falls within the same calendar week but is also one or two days too late.

The correct approach aligns with Rule 131, which states that periods are calculated from the date of notification (the day after posting), and Rule 134 specifies how to determine the exact expiry date.
